results.title: Animals in winter
results.creator_credit: Heinz Sielmann Productions and Heinz Sielmann
results.brief_description: The behaviour in winter of squirrels, hamsters, insects, frogs, butterflies and other creatures, showing how they cope with the rigours of cold and the shortage of food in order to survive until the spring. Intended for primary and secondary schools

results.title: Animals in modern life
results.creator_credit: ERPI Classroom Films and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Deals with the wide variety of uses to which animals are put in our modern civilisation - to furnish food, clothing materials, and power. Shows how animals have been domesticated and now, while power uses of animals are decreasing, more and more are being used for food and for clothing.

results.title: Animals hear in many ways. - Rev. ed.
results.creator_credit: Norman Bean Films, BFA Educational Media and George J. Holland
results.brief_description: Indicates that animals hear when sound vibrations produce similar vibrations in their own bodies. Shows that different parts of animals’ bodies may be specifically adapted to receive these vibrations. Shows the ways in which dogs, elephants, bats, fish, snakes and some insects hear. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Animals can bite
results.creator_credit: Pyramid Films, John Hart Films and John Hart
results.brief_description: Instructs children on how to avoid being bitten by animals encountered on the street and what to do when someone is bitten by any kind of animal. Suitable for primary school level.

results.title: Animals at work in nature
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Nicholas Dancy
results.brief_description: Explains that animals have highly-specialised body parts which enable them to adapt to their environment. With close-up photography, shows animals building homes, raising their young, and acquiring and storing food. Includes scenes of a woodpecker drilling in the bark of a tree, a mosquito sucking blood from a farmer’s arm, caterpillars spinning a web, ants carrying heavy loads of food, a caddis fly glueing materials together for its home, and beavers building a dam.
results.description: Explains that animals have highly-specialised body parts which enable them to adapt to their environment. results.title: Animals and their homes
results.brief_description: Various animal homes are evaluated as places for rearing young, in terms of protection afforded by environment, location, and building materials. The duck, grebe, beaver, stickle-back, rabbit, horned lark, robin, eagle, squirrel, gopher, prairie dog, wasp and cliff swallow are shown and discussed.

results.title: Animals and their foods
results.brief_description: To illustrate that animals are suited to eating different foods, the film shows animals that eat plants, some that eat meat, and others that eat both. It is explained that wild animals must search for food and all animals need food to live and grow.
results.description: To illustrate that animals are suited to eating different foods, the film shows animals that eat plants, some that eat meat, and others that eat both. It is explained that wild animals must search for food and all animals need food to live and grow.

results.title: Animals and Pam
results.creator_credit: Charles Cahill and Associates, Charles Cahill and Ralph Helfer
results.brief_description: Emphasises the point that while we may love and assist wild life, we must remember that they are wild and belong in their native habitat. Pam and her parents live in Africa. Finding a sick baby elephant one day, Pam leads him home, nurses him back to health, and, reluctantly, returns him to his jungle home.
